info.game_comments:
WE ASKED: Stephan James.

9 clues left unrevealed in Double Jeopardy!

(1, 1).clue: People from the Perth area of this country are "Sandgropers"

(2, 1).clue: You'll be A-OK with a TFT-LCD one of these basic parts of a desktop computer

(4, 1).clue: In 2015 about 6,500 athletes with intellectual disabilities, from 165 countries, came together in L.A. for this event

(5, 1).clue: This symbol helps you find posts on Twitter

(6, 1).clue: Jesse Owens, known as "the Buckeye Bullet", broke an astounding 3 world records & tied a 4th, all within 45 minutes, for this Big 10 school

(1, 2).clue: Sticky nickname for someone from Fayetteville or Charlotte

(2, 2).clue: A circuit that allows data to travel between a peripheral & a computer is a "local" this vehicle

(4, 2).clue: The USA's first humane society & today's leading voice for animal welfare, it's celebrating its 150th anniv. in 2016
(4, 2).correct response: the ASPCA (the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals)

(5, 2).clue: Its deadly demise in 1937 marked the end of the use of airships for commercial air transportation

(6, 2).clue: In 1935 Jesse broke the old world record of 26' 2 1/8" by a full half foot in this field event--a record that stood for an amazing 25 years

(1, 3).clue: Walloons are French-speaking residents of this country

(2, 3).clue: If your website is DDoSED, you've got problems because DDoS stands for distributed this

(4, 3).clue: Walt Disney designed the train logo for this program that distributes new playthings for kids at Christmas

(5, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew reports from the Brookfield Zoo in Chicago.)  The warm & soft wool of the alpaca is low in substances that irritate human skin, making it popular for garments that are this, meaning "unlikely to cause immunological reaction"

(6, 3).clue: (I'm Stephan James, and I play Jesse Owens in Race.)  Hitler didn't want the Olympics in Berlin, but this propaganda chief convinced him that the games could showcase Aryan superiority; Jesse had other ideas

(1, 4).clue: People from this city in the Distrito Federal call themselves Chilangos

(2, 4).clue: A pun on one of China's claims to fame, this is the nickname for China's Internet barriers

(4, 4).clue: Largely from its telethons, this program, whose logo is seen here, has had over $300 million pledged to the campaign

(5, 4).clue: In hockey it's 3 goals scored in a single game by the same player

(6, 4).clue: In 1926 Adi Dassler, father of this sportswear company, risked the wrath of the Nazis by having Jesse Owens wear his cleats

(1, 5).clue: Sting is a proud Geordie, from the area of Newcastle-upon-this river

(2, 5).clue: Different from emoticons, these pictographs come from the Japanese for "picture writing"

(4, 5).clue: The National Society for Crippled Children was later renamed this, after its famous stamp that bears a lily

(5, 5).clue: Latin for "have the body", this legal writ requires that a person held in custody be brought before the court

(6, 5).clue: (Stephan James delivers the last clue.)  Due to the climate of Hitler's Germany, USA's Jewish runners were pulled from this 4-man event; Ralph Metcalfe & a reluctant Owens stepped in, giving Jesse his historic 4th gold medal
(6, 5).correct response: the 4 × 100 meter relay (the 400 meter relay accepted)

(1, 1).clue: This Mideastern body of water through which big ships pass is rarely deeper than 300 feet

(2, 1).clue: It's a medicine taken to neutralize a specific poison & the hero usually finds it just in time

(3, 1).clue: This 1854 poem contains the lines "Theirs not to make reply, theirs not to reason why, theirs but to do and die"

(4, 1).clue: After Heraclius assumed the throne in 610, he replaced Latin as the official language with this

(5, 1).clue: A large wardrobe or movable cupboard

(1, 2).clue: The Central American area seen here is this type of narrow strip of land joining two larger land masses

(3, 2).clue: He's the very dramatic Russian seen here around 1900

(5, 2).clue: 7-letter word for the area close enough to be audible

(1, 3).clue: Extending 65 miles into the Atlantic Ocean off North America, its beaches attract visitors in droves

(2, 3).clue: The heart medicine digitalis comes from this flower that sounds like a vixen accessory

(3, 3).clue: He's the only human in the "Winnie-the-Pooh" stories

(4, 3).clue: The Byzantine Empire's overthrow of the Ostrogothic Kingdom paved the Lombards' way into what's now this country

(5, 3).clue: Comically vulgar or indecent in speech

(1, 4).clue: The inhabitants of this 76,000-square-mile peninsula are predominantly descendants of the Maya

(3, 4).clue: This sci-fi author's "C" novels include "Childhood's End" & "Cradle", about contact with an alien civilization

(4, 4).clue: In the 8th century this movement that barred the veneration of Christian images swept throughout the empire

(5, 4).clue: urbandictionary.com says they hate "corporations and everything mainstream, yet... buy Apple products"

(1, 5).clue: 2 nations share the 220-mile-wide delta of this Asian river

(3, 5).clue: "Chirp the first" is the first chapter of this Dickens short novel

(4, 5).clue: The empire's ships sailed as far as Britain for tin from this historic county at the island's southwest tip

(5, 5).clue: Pertaining to the throat, though it sounds like it means pertaining to an area near the stomach

(0, 0).clue: In one version of a 19th century quote, "There is room and health... away from the crowds" so you're urged to do these 2 words
